channel.title: JReversePro
channel.description:
Just looking around, I ended up looking through this:
http://jreversepro.blogspot.com/
JReversePro is a java disassembler and decompiler. It is also open source, and comes with it's own little API. What does the API come with? A simple Class I/O library, instruction manipulation library, and a MOTHER FUCKING AST. Anyone want to mess with this? If so, post your code :)
Looking through the source, it looks like you'd have to change some things if you want to work with it, and it looks like you'd have to write the AST-to-bytecode writer.

item.title: JReversePro
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

The naming is a very BCELesque but I’m sure that you could steal a bit of code and the design to create your own version.

Edit: Half of it is not implemented. Its even more bare-bones than BCEL when it comes to instruction parsing. Don’t bother.

Read full topic

item.title: JReversePro
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

i am almost certain krichevskoy and i had a look at this and it was fucking horrible

ie: it couldnt decompile anything because it kept hitting infinite loops on simple methods

Read full topic

item.title: JReversePro
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

Just looking around, I ended up looking through this:

jreversepro.blogspot.com

JReversePro

Java Decompiler / Disassembler.

JReversePro is a java disassembler and decompiler. It is also open source, and comes with it’s own little API. What does the API come with? A simple Class I/O library, instruction manipulation library, and a MOTHER FUCKING AST. Anyone want to mess with this? If so, post your code

Looking through the source, it looks like you’d have to change some things if you want to work with it, and it looks like you’d have to write the AST-to-bytecode writer.
